intro: Cinchona acutifolia, commonly known as the acuteleaf quinine tree, is a species native to the Andean regions of South America. It is a member of the Rubiaceae family and is characterized by its lance-shaped leaves and clusters of small, white flowers. The plant produces red, fleshy berries that contain seeds, and it is known for its historical use in the production of quinine, a compound used to treat malaria. Its botanical significance lies in its role in medicinal botany and its adaptation to high-altitude environments.
